questions.question: An infant has a congenital bronchopulmonary malformation as shown in the CT scan givenbelow. Which of the following is most likely to supply the marked structure?
questions.explanation: The given CT shows an intralobar pulmonary sequestration of the left lung. The thoracicaorta commonly supplies the sequestered lobe of the lung.Pulmonary sequestration is an area of embryonic lung tissue, separate from the lung. It receivesblood supply from an anomalous systemic artery from the aorta. It is of two types:•Extralobar sequestration occurs primarily on the left side and blood supply is usually from thethoracic or upper abdominal aorta•• Intralobar sequestration occurs in the lower lobes predominantly (>95%). It is equallydistributed between the right and left lower lobe and blood supply is from the descending thoracic1140aorta, venous drainage via pulmonary veinsTreatment involves resection of the pulmonary sequestration.

questions.question: 1129A 50-year-old patient on DOTS therapy was rushed to the casualty after having massivehemoptysis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.A: Intubation is done into the non-bleeding lung.
options.B: Massive hemoptysis is defined as expectoration of over 750 mL of blood within 24-hours.Presence of significant cavitary disease is an indication for urgent surgery.d) Bleeding is most likely due to pulmonary artery erosion.Question 4:Where is Rasmussen's aneurysm seen?a) Internal thoracic arteryb) Pulmonary artery

questions.explanation: Massive hemoptysis is defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hourperiod. Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medicalemergency.Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is calledmassive hemoptysis. This includes blood loss of >600mL/24h or >150ml/h which can floodthe anatomical dead space of the lung.Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from thepulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion.The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood lossitself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority.After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleedingis controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of theinvolved area is also done in some cases.Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis:• Presence of a fungus ball• Presence of a lung abscess• Presence of significant cavitary disease• Failure to control the bleeding.

questions.question: A 50-year-old chronic smoker with left-sided lung cancer is rushed to the emergencydepartment with massive hemoptysis. On examination, pulse - 102 bpm, BP - 80/50 mmHg,RR - 30/min. Which of the following will be part of your management plan for this patient?
questions.explanation: The left side is most likely to be the bleeding side in this patient. Hence, the patient should beplaced in the left lateral decubitus position to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Also, aCT scan is not indicated as he is hemodynamically unstable.Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:First priorities are to maintain the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamicstatus by administering IV fluids.••Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stablepatients.• If the bleeding side is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position, withthe bleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung and given supplementaloxygen.• If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should beintubated and undergo emergency bronchoscopy.• The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy.• Control the hemorrhage:.Endobronchially with Nd:YAG laser or bronchial occlusion• Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization• Electrocauterization.• Surgically with resection of the involved lobeThe cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

questions.question: A 54-year-old comes to the casualty with a history of massive hemoptysis. His routineinvestigation and chest X-ray were normal. Which of the following you will not do to preventhemoptysis?
questions.explanation: Procoagulant drugs are not used to prevent hemoptysis. Procoagulant drugs like vasopressin areindicated only if there is an abnormal coagulation profile.Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a24-h period.Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:•⚫ First priorities are to secure the airway, optimize oxygenation and stabilize the hemodynamicstatus by administering IV fluids.• Chest X-ray is the first investigation of choice. CT scan is done only in hemodynamically stablepatients.If the bleeding site is known, the patient should be placed in a lateral decubitus position with thebleeding side down to prevent aspiration into the unaffected lung. Supplemental oxygen should begiven.1142• If large-volume bleeding continues or the airway is compromised, the patient should beintubated and undergo an emergency bronchoscopy.• The bleeding site is localized using flexible/rigid bronchoscopy.• Control the hemorrhage:•Endobronchially with Nd:YAG laser or bronchial occlusion• Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization• Electrocauterization• Surgically with resection of the involved lobeThe cause of the hemoptysis must be determined to definitively prevent a recurrence.

questions.question: A 20-year-old man presents with h/o sudden breathlessness while watching television. Uponexamination, he is noticed to be 6 ft tall and very lean. He is not breathless at the moment.Chest X-ray reveals a right-sided pneumothorax of 1.5 cm. He does not smoke or drink.Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary pneumothorax. The next step would be todischarge and follow up in 2-4 weeks as the size is <2cm.Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. It can be primary orsecondary.Primary pneumothorax can occur spontaneously due to rupture of the apical blebs. Risk factorsinclude:•Males > Females•Young, tall, and thin individuals•Family history•SmokingIt resolves spontaneously hence just follow-up is usually needed in most cases.Secondary pneumothorax occurs due to some underlying pathology. Risk factors include:•Age> 50 years• Smoking• COPD• Asthma•Cystic fibrosis• Infection (pneumonia, abscess, and tuberculosis)•Interstitial lung disease• Connective tissue disease• Procedures (subclavian lines, thoracentesis, bronchoscopy, and mechanical ventilation)•Blunt trauma1143Patients with pneumothorax present with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physicalexamination will reveal:• An enlarged hemithorax• Decreased chest movements• Hyper-resonance on percussion• Absent vocal fremitus• Diminished breath soundsDiagnosis is made by chest X-ray (best initial test), CT scan, or USG.Management of pneumothorax:•••Primary pneumothorax<2 cm size: Discharge and follow-up in 2-4 weeks>2 cm size and/or breathless: Aspirate with 16 G cannula → If fails, place a chest drain of size8-14 FrSecondary pneumothorax• <1 cm size: High-flow oxygen with observation for 24 hours• 1-2 cm size: Aspirate with 16 G cannula → If fails, place a chest drain of size 8-14 Fr• >2 cm size: Place chest drain of size 8-14 Fr

questions.question: The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on :
questions.explanation: The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on the presence of barcode sign, absence ofthe sliding lung and absence of comet-tail artifacts that are seen in relation to a normallung-pleural interface.Normally, lung sliding corresponds to the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on theparietal pleura that occurs with respiration. It is a dynamic sign and can be identified onultrasound as horizontal movement along the pleural line.In pneumothorax, the air separates visceral and parietal pleura and prevents visualization ofvisceral pleura. Hence lung sliding is absent and typical to and fro movement and shimmering ofthe pleural lines will not be present.Comet tail artifacts are seen in the normal lungs due to the acoustic impedance differencesbetween water and air, whereas it is absent in pneumothorax.The image given below shows a sliding sign seen in a normal lung.1144REFT LUNGSlide signB-ModeAPleurallineM-ModeOption A: The quad sign is seen in pleural effusion. It consists of four lines representing thepleura, rib, fluid, and lung.Option C: The motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal 'waves,'and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand'. The resultant pictureis one that resembles waves crashing onto the sand and is therefore called the 'seashore sign' andis present in normal lungs.

questions.question: A patient presents with breathlessness to the casualty after a motorcycle accident. Onexamination, the left chest is hyper-resonant on percussion and shows reduced air entry overthe same side. His pulse is 110 bpm, RR - 25/min, BP - 80/45mmHg, and JVP was elevated.What will be your immediate management?

options.A: Insert a wide bore needle in 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line
options.C: Insert a chest tube in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The first line of management intension pneumothorax is to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space just anterior tothe midaxillary line.Pneumothorax is the abnormal accumulation of air in the pleural space. Tension pneumothoraxdevelops when air enters the pleural space through a point that acts as a one-way valve. More andmore air enters with every breath without any way for the air to escape. This is a medicalemergency where the patient can quickly deteriorate.A patient with pneumothorax presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A physicalexamination will reveal:• An enlarged hemithorax• Decreased chest movements• Hyper-resonance on percussion• Absent vocal fremitus• Diminished breath soundsIn addition to the above findings, a tension pneumothorax would also have the following:• Deviation of trachea to the opposite side1145• Distended neck vein•Cyanosis•Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise:• Hypotension• Tachycardia• Low O2 saturation• Loss of consciousnessA diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is usually made based on the clinical findings. If the tensionin the pleural cavity is not relieved, the patient can die due to hemodynamic collapse. Hence,treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.The management of tension pneumothorax is to convert a tension pneumothorax into a simplepneumothorax. This can be done by rapid decompression using a wide-bore cannula on theaffected side, followed by the insertion of a chest tube for definitive management.The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:• Anterior to the mid-axillary line• Above the level of the nipple•⚫ Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscleTriangle of safetyOMARROWNote:If immediate management is asked, the answer will be to insert a wide-bore needle in the 5thintercostal space in the midaxillary line.If definitive management is asked, the answer will be to insert an intercostal tube in the triangleof safety.1146Suture placementdrainTriangleQaudingdistinsertionOMARROW

questions.question: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a stab wound to his rightchest following a fight at the local bar. His vitals are normal. On examination, the trachea is1131central and a penetrating wound is noted on the right chest. A sucking sound is heard duringinspiration. Which of the following is the initial management in this case?

options.A: Occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides
options.B: Placing chest drain at the site of the wound

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of open pneumothorax. Initial management, in this case,is to apply occlusive dressing taped on the 3 sides.Open pneumothorax is due to a large open defect in the chest, making intrathoracic pressureequal to atmospheric pressure. In this defect, the air is preferentially drawn through the defect,rather than through the trachea. Air gets accumulated causing pneumothorax leading tohypoventilation and hypoxia. It acts as a sucking chest wound. Sucking sound during inspirationis characteristic.It is managed initially with the application of a sterile occlusive dressing tapped on the 3 sides.Then a chest tube is inserted at a different site, away from the wound.

questions.question: A patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and breathlessness. On examination,decreased breath sounds and dull note on percussion is noted on the left side. A chest X-ray isgiven below. USG-guided aspiration revealed frank pus. Chest tube was inserted but therewas no improvement in symptoms. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of empyema thoracis. Symptoms failed to resolve ontreatment with chest tube insertion, hence it is managed by VATS debridement.Empyema thoracis is an infection of the pleural space. It commonly progresses from an acutephase with thin fluid that can be drained completely with a chest tube or small-bore catheter to amore turbid and thick fluid that might loculate. It is an exudative effusion. It can be caused dueto:•Underlying infection of the lung (pneumonia or abscess)•Complication after chest surgery• Infected hemothorax•Complication of Pleural effusion1147• Trauma (esophageal perforation)•Osteomyelitis of ribsAn empyema thoracis on chest x-ray can mimic a pleural effusion or a lung abscess.The procedure VATS (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) is used in the debridement ofempyema. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed for dependent drainage.If VATS fails to re-expand the lung after drainage, a more radical procedure (decortication) maybe done.

questions.explanation: The given clinical features of myasthenia gravis along with the CT scan image showing an anteriormediastinal mass are suggestive of thymoma. questions.question: A toddler with cough and progressive breathing difficulty was found to have a poorly definedsolid mass in the mediastinum. What is the most common mediastinal mass in this agegroup?
questions.explanation: The most common mediastinal mass in young children is neurogenic tumors (50%-60%). In mostcases (< 4 years of age), they are invariably malignant.The most common mediastinal masses in adults are thymomas and thymic cysts.

questions.question: What is the most common benign tumor of the lung?
questions.explanation: The most common benign tumor of the lung is hamartoma.Hamartoma is a developmental abnormality containing mesothelial and endothelial elements.They are manifested by the overgrowth of cartilage. It is typically seen in 40-60 years of age, morecommon in males.It is usually seen in the periphery of the lung and grows slowly. questions.question: Which of the following is true about bronchial carcinoid?
questions.explanation: Bronchial carcinoid is usually asymptomatic.Bronchial carcinoids are the most indolent of the spectrum of pulmonary neuroendocrine tumors.They arise from the Kulchitsky cells in the bronchial epithelium. Most tumors are confined to themain stem bronchus and commonly project into the lumen. It is associated with MEN 1.Most patients affected are <40 years and it is not related to smoking. It is usually asymptomaticand only 10% of bronchial carcinoids give rise to carcinoid syndrome which is characterized byintermittent attacks of:• Diarrhea• Flushing.• Bronchospasm• CyanosisBronchial carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and do not metastasize to distant sites. Theyhave a good prognosis and can be easily resected.

questions.question: During a health checkup in a factory, a 52-year-old worker complained of progressive coughand weight loss for the past 6 months. The biopsy sample obtained stained positive for calretinin.Which of the following is false about this condition?

options.A: Immunohistochemical analysis will be positive for TTF-1.1136
options.C: Asbestos exposure is the major risk factor.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with biopsy showing positive calretinin is suggestive of mesothelioma.The immunohistochemical analysis will be negative for TTF-1 in mesothelioma. TTF-1 is positive1156in adenocarcinoma of the lung.Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumor of the pleura. Exposure to asbestos is themajor known risk factor. questions.explanation: The procedure that is shown is Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) and empyema is nota contraindication for the procedure.VATS is a minimally invasive surgical technique used to diagnose and treat disorders of thethoracic cavity. It also allows direct visualization of the pleural cavity.Lung biopsy and recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications for VATS. Otherconditions where VATS is used include:•Malignancies••· EmpyemaOesophageal surgeries• Patent ductus areteriosus• Undiagnosed pleural effusion•Pneumonectomy• Lobectomy• Pleural biopsy• PleurodesisThe patient is usually positioned with the diseased side up in a lateral decubitus position.A double lumen endotracheal-bronchial tube is placed by the anesthetist for single-lungventilation. At the end of the procedure, chest drains are placed to allow dependent drainage.The following precautions must be noted before placing the drains:• The drain should exit the skin anterior to the midaxillary line. If this is not done then the patientwill have to lie on the tube which will cause pain and obstruction of the tube.•The course of the drain should be oblique to the skin, chest wall, and pleura, or else it will leadto kinking of the tube.1159The main advantage of VATS is that a large incision is avoided. This causes less postoperative painand a rapid recovery. However, VATS procedure limits the ability of the surgeon to palpate thelung to identify occult metastases.

questions.question: What is the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending artery while performing CABG?
questions.explanation: The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery is the conduit of choice forthe left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The most important criterion in conduitselection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammaryartery or internal thoracic artery.Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correctorder of graft patency in a patient undergoing CABG procedure.Venous grafts:• The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward toharvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.• The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50-60 percent.Arterial grafts:• The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit ofchoice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as asecond or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploicartery and the inferior epigastric artery.•• Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man has been in the ICU for the past 1 month due to end-stage liver failure. Heis not eligible for a transplant and his doctors have said there is nothing they can do at thisstage. His family has consented to organ donation once his heart stops. Which of thecategories of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modifiedMaastricht classification?
questions.explanation: The patient would fall under category III.Modified Maastricht classification- Categories of non-heart-beating donors:•Uncontrolled transplant team not present or prepared-• Category I - includes victims of accident and suicide who are found dead at the scene andresuscitation is deemed pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture).Category II - donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophes who arebrought to emergency departments while being resuscitated by ambulance personnel or who diein the department. Other sources include patients suffering an isolated brain injury, anoxia, andstroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission.•Category V - Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care.• Controlled transplant team present and prepared-Category III encompasses patients who are dying, often in an intensive care unit. These are thepatients awaiting cardiac arrest where the treating clinicians have decided to withdraw treatmentand not commence resuscitation for various reasons.1160• Category IV - comprises patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after thedetermination of brain death.1161
